PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  A project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) is required to undertake due diligence 
and prepare the major project documents for the investment loan to support the structuring of 
the sustainable Public – Private Earthquake Insurance Pool, and drawing from existing models 
in Latin America, Turkey, as well as Indonesia and Taiwan. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
 
2.  The  consulting  risk modeler  will  (i)  continue  to  upgrade the  earthquake risk model 
initiated under the S-CDTA1 and develop the pricing of insurance and reinsurance products,     
(ii) initiate and provide ongoing training on risk modelling to the project management unit staffed 
from Government and industry. The financial consultants will also undertake the institutional and 
project development activities in consultation with international insurance and legal experts:     
(iii) Establish the governance arrangements of the pool, including the independence of the 
board of directors; (iv) Develop and undertake the stress testing of the pool’s business plan, 
investment policy and reserve funds; (v) Identify optimum funding structures for the EQ Pool, 
both in terms of debt and equity. 
 
3.  The TA will assist the government  in accordance with ADB policy requirements. The TA 
outcome will be to produce an agreed project design, feasibility study, and implementation 
arrangements suitable for ADB financing. The TA’s scope will include the phased preparation of 
the project loan. Details are in Appendix 4.  PIRA members, who are invested in the EQ 
insurance pool, will jointly hold ownership of the risk model and the underlying data with the 
regulator’s representative.  They will be represented on the Board.  The risk model will be ceded 
to the pool upon its legal incorporation, to facilitate continuous premium rate calibration.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement

The government will provide counterpart support in the form of office space, communication 
facilities for consultants, and other in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimate is presented 
in Table A4.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
 
6.  The implementation of the PPTA will require the services of a multidisciplinary team 
comprising international and national consultants (in the form of a firm or as individuals). Twelve 
(12) consultants (6 international and 6 national) will be recruited through an international firm 
and as individuals in accordance with the ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended  from  time  to  time).  An  international  firm  will  be  engaged  on  a  QCBS  basis  to 
undertake the demand analysis of the new insurance product, lead the domestic consultants 
and coordinate with the individual international experts on overall project delivery.  Individual 
international financial specialists will be hired on a lump-sum basis to undertake the tasks of (i) 
team leader, governance and funding structure, (ii) business plan, investment plan, reserve 
funding,. Individual international insurance and reinsurance expert (s) as well as an international 
legal expert will be hired on a lump-sum basis to provide specific inputs to the risk modeller and 
the international consulting team.  Catalytics, the open platform risk modelling firm, will be 
engaged on a single source selection and lump-sum contract basis, to run the model and 
provide related capacity building for the project management unit.

7.  The qualifications and outline terms of reference for the PPTA consultants are described 
in paras. 7 to 15.  
 
8.  Financial Specialist/Team Leader. The international expert should have proven senior 
experience in managing a start-up financial company (insurance or commercial bank), including 
structuring  the  corporate  investment  prospectus  and  developing  the  corporate  governance 
guidelines.  As team leader this expert will be responsible for all TA outputs and liaison with 
Government, the private sector and the ADB project officer. The expert will seek and coordinate 
the  inputs  of  all  team  members  and  ensure  the  quality  of  technical,  financial,  and 
implementation arrangements-related documents. Specifically, the expert will : (i) coordinate 
with Catalytics on the risk model that will support the structure of the EQ pool; (ii) coordinate 
with the international financial expert on the preparation of the EQ pool’s supporting business 
plan, investment plan and reserve funding; (iii) develop the appropriate funding structure of the 
EQ pool to ensure its long term sustainability; (iv) develop the investment prospectus and (v) 
lead the investor roadshow to ensure appropriate capitalization / funding of the pool.  The expert 
will  also  lead  the  recruitment  of  the  Project  Management  Unit  staff  and  coordinate  with 
Catalytics on the appropriate training of the supporting staff members.  The national finance 
expert will work closely with and support the international expert.  
 
9.  Financial  Specialist/Business  Plan,  Investment  Plan,  Reserve  Funding.  The 
financial specialist will have proven expertise in developing commercially viable plans.  The 
expert  will  (i)  develop  and  undertake  the  stress  testing  of  the  EQ  pool’s  business  plan, 
investment plan and reserve funding requirements, (ii) assess and provide dedicated IT systems 
to monitor portfolio exposure database; (iii) develop the operational monitoring mechanisms 
related to premium collection, claims settlement, and loss assessment. The national finance 
expert will work closely with and support the international expert.

Appendix 4  5 
 
10.  Finance and Economic Specialist/Team Leader of the national consultants.  The 
finance and economic specialist will have expertise in undertaking market demand for new 
commercial  financial  products.    The  expert  will  have  in-depth  knowledge  of  survey 
methodologies and data sources, used internationally and in the Philippines. The expert will 
review the market conditions for non-life insurance product penetration in the Philippines and in 
coordination with the members of the Working Group, assess the demand for the new EQ 
insurance cover.  The expert will also act as team leader of the national consultants. 
 
11.  Insurance and Reinsurance  Experts (2). The international experts must have hands-
on  experience  in  developing  disaster  risk  models  in  middle  income  as  well  as  developed 
economy (ies).  Expertise in working with an internationally-rated insurance broker or major 
reinsurance company is a requirement will provide discrete and specific advisory to the  project 
consultants and Catalytics on the following – as per the guidance of the Team Leader and ADB:  
(i)  Develop  insurance  policy  rates,  terms  and  conditions,  including  those  for  parametric 
products;  (ii)  Prepare  underwriting,  including  the  assessment  of  distribution  channels  (e.g. 
cellphones, utility bills)  and supporting technology (e.g. GSIS) to identify policyholders (by 
property and person); (iii) Audit for risk reserving; (iv) Risk transfer strategy mainly through 
overseas reinsurance arrangements, as well as capital market solutions; (v) Identify optimum 
funding structures for the EQ Pool, both in terms of debt and equity; (vi) Confirm all regulations 
currently established in the Philippines, support the institutional structure and operationalization 
of  the  EQ  Pool.  The  national  insurance  specialist  will  work  closely  with  and  support  the 
international experts. 
 
12.   Legal Expert.  The international expert must have extensive knowledge of and hands-
on experience in the legal and regulatory frameworks enabling the development of insurance 
and financial mechanisms.  Ideally, the expert will also have a working knowledge of disaster 
risk  frameworks  established  internationally  and  will  be  conversant  with  the  supporting 
legislation.  The expert will perform the following tasks:  (i) Review the Philippine Development 
Plan 2011–2016 as well as the DRRM Act of 2010 (Republic Act [RA] No. 10121) and its 
implementing rules and regulations, and the supporting Climate Change Act of 2009 (RA 9729) 
and  its  implementing  rules  and  regulations;  (ii)  Assess  the  existing  enabling  regulatory 
frameworks and propose solutions toward structuring a public - private Earthquake insurance 
pool  or  private  reinsurance  company;  (iii)  Develop  the  guiding  regulatory  and  governance 
framework for review by public and private stakeholders and ADB; (iv) Present findings at 
workshops and take required action to modify proposed framework in a manner to ensure long-
term sustainability of the agreed DRF public – private structure; (v) Provide inception, interim, 
and final reports, as well as regular post-training workshop reports to ADB and public private 
stakeholders in Government and the insurance industry in the Philippines. 
 
13.  Legal Specialist. The expert should have a legal degree with experience working on 
international project assignments in the country and possibly, the Asia-Pacific region.  The 
national expert will review the legal and regulatory framework together with the international 
expert.  
 
14.  Financial Analyst. The expert should preferably have an advanced degree in finance 
and experience working on due diligence and credit risk assessment of a commercial bank or 
insurance company. The national expert will work closely with and support the international 
experts.

Appendix 4  6 
 
15.  Insurance Analyst. The expert should preferably have an advanced degree in finance 
and experience working in the Philippine insurance industry. The national expert will work 
closely with and support the international experts.  
 
16.  Information Technology expert.  The expert should have extensive experience in 
developing and customizing IT systems supporting portfolio risk assessment in an insurance 
company  or  commercial  bank.  The  national  expert  will  work  closely  with  the  international 
financial experts and risk modeller.  
 
17.  Biometric Data expert. The expert should have a strong commercial record either with 
a major utility, cellphone company, health insurance on developing data and billing systems 
linked with personal identification, including biometric identification.  The national expert will 
work closely with the international financial, insurance and modelling experts.  
 
18.  Project  Meeting  and  Workshop  Coordinator.  The  expert  should  have  extensive 
experience  with  administering  large  international  projects  in  the  country.    The  expert  will:           
(i) prepare and organize workshops, seminars, conferences; (ii) undertake prompt and detailed 
minutes for circulation within 24 hours; (iii) prepare all supporting material on a timely basis;      
(v) coordinate across involved stakeholders. The national expert will work closely with and 
support the project team.  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  IC under DOF is the executing agency. IC and DOF will provide counterpart support in 
the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  access  to  studies  and  data,  provision  of  office  space, 
communication facilities for consultants, and other in-kind contribution.  The TA completion date 
is August 31, 2014.
